Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Alleviating Social Skills Disorders through Avatars and Game Based Learning
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Phase I project seeks to combine proven social skills training techniques and curriculum with animation and game-based learning by developing easily accessible software. The prevalence of autism spectrum disorder births, as reported by the Center for Disease Control and Prevention, has risen by 110% from 1 in 150 to 1 in 68 births in the past decade. Third-party research finds that individuals whose social skills deficits persist into adulthood are more likely to suffer from anxiety, depression, and suicide ideation. The software is currently personal computer (PC) only and has been tested with great success. This project now seeks to develop a browser-based version in an effort to become device agnostic and more available to the 129,315 schools and over 50,000 hospitals and private practices nationally according to Census data. This project will also begin exploring uncharted territory of integrating virtual reality into social skills training to further increase effectiveness. Given its potential impact on student engagement and socialization and the $50 billion spent annually on special needs students, the software is commercially viable. It is also flexible enough to be used with curriculum for speech therapy, bullying awareness, foreign languages, life-skills training, job training, and socially-conscious role playing.


This project aims to bring the first generation PC version of the social skills training software to additional platforms: browsers and virtual reality. A browser version is required to eliminate hardware obstacles for more widespread and convenient access throughout the social skills training software market. Technical challenges for browser-based development include establishing a continuous server-client connection to record interactions, compressing streamed data, synchronizing audio/video, and testing peripherals. Bringing the software to virtual reality (VR) is achievable, but costlier and more complicated than the browser-based version. The first innovation will be creating VR software that is flexible enough for future technological advancements and use across various platforms. The most profound innovation of our VR platform will be building collaborative/social VR software that can sync live input/capture from multiple users on multiple devices in one virtual space. This requires extensive development and testing to get a uniquely customized server-client system in place. The software will incorporate heat mapping and eye tracking technology to help evaluate the effectiveness of learning experiences through internal user experience, and more formal studies by our university partners. The software is expected to be the first VR based social skills training platforms and will unlock boundless new social interactive and engaging learning opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SiLAS is a system that will revolutionize how we currently teach social skills by combining proven social skills training techniques and technology to create an engaging and effective learning experience for students with social skills deficiencies. With a curriculum designed by leading social skills special education practitioners, and software and technology built by experienced game designers, education software experts, and an Emmy award-winning children's programming director, SiLAS presents a unique solution to a growing problem.

Social skills is a very important and impactful aspect of education for children diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder, and current education tools haven't changed much in the past thirty years.  Most curricula are paper-based, and the curricula that have been ported to software use mostly paper-based approaches to teaching and learning. SiLAS is different because our technology provides a platform for learning that both students and teachers can use creatively, following the content of our curricula and, crucially, using it with their own lesson plans as well.

The software’s efficacy was proven in research studies by Kean and Princeton Universities before the start of our Phase I project with our PC-version. To quote Amy Freyberger, the researcher at Princeton who studied SiLAS, “comparing SiLAS with a paper-and-pencil social skills class, I found that SiLAS resulted in far greater improvement in social skills. This improvement was still present three months after classes ended, which shows carryover. Not only did SiLAS parents observe improved social skills in their children, but were also far more satisfied with the skills their children learned. SiLAS leads to greater generalization of the social skills, allows children to practice their skills in a variety of safe contexts, and holds a great deal of promise for social skills instruction to children with autism.”

The Phase I proposal had two main goals: the development of a device agnostic browser-based version of SiLAS and the development of a virtual reality (VR) prototype of SiLAS. These two new versions of SiLAS represent major innovations on our original idea and product, a 2D PC-only software. The PC-version of SiLAS was innovative in the fact that it was the first product to bring collaboration through real time animation to the social skills classroom. The browser-based version of SiLAS builds on this innovation by being the first browser-based social skills software to incorporate these values alongside new and improved hardware and peripherals - essential components to help keep students engaged (Kapp, Karl M., Lucas Blair, and Rich Mesch). Bringing SiLAS into virtual reality will further our innovation and lead to increased efficacy and greater possibilities, through improved interactions, more accurate student performance tracking, and an eventual job training program.

The browser-based version of SiLAS was developed successfully. In education, many schools are moving to Chromebooks and other cheaper ways to get students online (Schaffhauser). Being browser-based ensures that SiLAS will remain accessible to these schools. Additionally, students have the ability to begin work on one computer’s browser, then login to another browser and retrieve their work. This is beneficial for teachers who work in multiple rooms per day, students who learn in multiple rooms during the day, or students who would like to continue to work at home with parents. The browser-based version of SiLAS, in fact, exceeded the scope of the Phase I project. In response to insights from customer interviews during Phase I, SiLAS has the capability of generating and tracking student performance data that fuels data-driven instruction and gives schools the ability to prove student progress.

Aside from data-management, the development processes of the browser and virtual reality versions of SiLAS were streamlined. All assets and infrastructure are shared between versions. As a result, instead of having a 2D browser-based version all avatars are now 3D. This is not just an aesthetic improvement; with a look and feel that students are more familiar with through their own use of video games, SiLAS inherently becomes more engaging. In addition to this improvement, the VR version of SiLAS was able to be built upon the infrastructure of the browser-based version reducing development time and costs.

The feasibility of a virtual reality social skills program was demonstrated through the successful development of a VR version of SiLAS in Phase I. Through informal user-testing, the VR software has received extremely positive reviews and will now be extensively studied. The study will explore how students with disabilities can interact with virtual reality as well as the efficacy of social skills training through virtual reality. This study will inform further development of the VR version of SiLAS so that it can be brought to market like the browser-based version of SiLAS. SiLAS has already benefited over 250 student in the United States and is expanding rapidly to other schools, hospitals, and private practices.
